questions.question: A 12-year-old patient presents with a history of sinusitis and now has swollen, red eyelids, pain with eye movement, and restricted extraocular motion. There is no proptosis, and CT imaging shows diffuse inflammation of the orbital tissues without abscess formation. According to Chandler's classification, what is the most likely stage of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Orbital cellulitis Explanation: Orbital cellulitis involves inflammation of the orbital tissues with pain on eye movement and restricted mobility but without abscess formation . There is no proptosis or pus collection, which is consistent with Stage II of Chandler’s classification. Chandler’s Classification of Orbital Cellulitis Stage Description Key Features I - Preseptal cellulitis Infection confined to the eyelid Eyelid swelling, no ocular involvement II - Orbital cellulitis Infection spreads to the orbit Pain with eye movement, restricted mobility, no abscess formation III - Subperiosteal abscess Pus collection beneath periosteum Localized pus, proptosis, pain on movement, swelling IV - Orbital abscess Pus collection within the orbital tissues Severe proptosis, potential vision loss, risk of optic nerve damage V - Cavernous sinus thrombosis Spread of infection to the cavernous sinus Bilateral eye involvement, headache, cranial nerve palsies

questions.question: During a total maxillectomy for an extensive malignant tumor, the surgeon is required to remove several structures to ensure complete resection. Which of the following structures is not typically removed during this procedure?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Zygomatic arch Explanation: During a total maxillectomy, the surgeon typically removes the hard palate and orbital floor and often involves areas around the ethmoid sinus. However, the zygomatic arch is not typically removed unless the tumor is specifically involved. Maxillectomy: Incision: A Weber-Fergusson incision or similar approach is often used to gain access. Type Structures Removed Medial Maxillectomy Middle turbinate Inferior turbinate Ethmoid sinus Maxillary sinus. Infrastructural Maxillectomy Extends to include the upper alveolar ridge & adjoining hard palate . Subtotal Maxillectomy Removal of the entire Maxilla. Total Maxillectomy Removal of all the above structures along with the Orbital Floor . Radical Maxillectomy Total maxillectomy plus Orbital exenteration. Bony box resection involves removing the maxilla as a unit containing the tumour to ensure complete excision of cancerous tissues. This approach maintains a clear boundary between the tumour and healthy tissues. Reference: Cumming’s Review of Otorhinolaryngology, Page - 98 Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition, Page - 83, 85

questions.question: A 65-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction, facial swelling, and proptosis. Imaging reveals a malignancy in the Sinonasal region. According to Lederman’s classification, which of the following tumor locations is categorized as mesostructural ?

options.B: Extension to the respiratory part of the nasal cavity.
options.C: Extending to sphenoid sinus and the orbit.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Extension to the respiratory part of the nasal cavity Explanation: Extension to the respiratory part of the nasal cavity is categorised as mesostructural in Lederman’s classification. Lederman's classification divides sinonasal malignancies based on their anatomical location into three categories using two horizontal reference lines: Horizontal Lines of Sebileau: These lines help delineate the categories by passing through the floors of the orbits and the antra. Vertical Lines: Extend down the medial walls of the orbit, separating the ethmoid sinuses and nasal fossa from the maxillary sinuses. Areas Structures Involved Prognosis Suprastructure Ethmoid Sphenoid (Option C) Frontal sinuses Olfactory area of the nose (Option A) . Poor prognosis Mesostructure Maxillary sinus Respiratory part of the nasal cavity. Better prognosis than suprastructural category. Infrastructure Alveolar process (Option D) of maxilla Better Prognosis

questions.question: A 62-year-old man presents with nasal obstruction and facial swelling. Imaging shows a malignancy in the maxillary sinus. The oncologist uses Ohngren’s line to assess the prognosis. According to Ohngren’s line, which tumour location indicates a better prognosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Below Ohngren’s line Explanation: Tumours below Ohngren’s line generally have a better prognosis than those above the line. Fig: Diagrammatic representation of Ohngren's line Ohngren's Line is an imaginary anatomical plane used in the assessment of sinonasal malignancies (Maxillary). It extends from the medial canthus of the eye to the angle of the mandible. Helps in classifying the extent and prognosis of sinonasal tumors. Ohngren’s Classification: Suprastructural Tumors (Above Ohngren’s Line): Tumors located above the line, which includes the ethmoid and frontal sinuses . Generally have a poorer prognosis . The involvement of the ethmoid and frontal sinuses often indicates a more advanced disease. Intrastructural Tumors (Below Ohngren’s Line): Tumors located below Ohngren's line, primarily involving the maxillary sinus and nasal cavity. Tumors confined below this line tend to have a better prognosis. They are usually less advanced and less likely to have spread extensively compared to those above the line.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male carpenter presents with symptoms of persistent nasal congestion, facial swelling, and occasional nasal bleeding. He has a long history of working in the hardwood furniture industry for 30 years. CT scan reveals findings, as shown in the image. Which type of carcinoma is he most at risk for?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Adenocarcinoma Explanation: Long-term exposure to hardwood dust has been linked to an increased risk of developing adenocarcinoma , particularly in the sinuses. In contrast, exposure to softwood dust is more specifically associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinoma. Neoplasms of

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and anosmia. A CT scan reveals an invasive mass in the nasal cavity, and a biopsy confirms the diagnosis of olfactory neuroblastoma. Which classification system is commonly used to stage olfactory neuroblastoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Kadish Classification Explanation: Kadish Classification is the most widely used system for staging olfactory neuroblastoma. Olfactory Neuroblastoma (Esthesioneuroblastoma): Originates from the Olfactory Epithelium in the upper third of the nasal cavity which is characterised by neuroblastic differentiation and can be locally aggressive with a tendency to invade adjacent structures. Bimodal peaks of incidence (10-20 years & 50-60 years) Symptoms: Early Symptoms: Unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis (nosebleeds). Advanced Symptoms: Tumour invades the orbit or surrounding structures, causing proptosis, headache, epiphora, diplopia, and blurred vision. Metastasis: Lymph node metastases in the neck can occur in 10-15% of cases. Diagnosis: Intranasal or Endoscopic Examination: Reveals a friable, cherry-red, polypoidal mass Highly vascular, so biopsy should be preceded by imaging studies. Imaging Studies: CT Scan: Shows tumour extent, and possible erosion of cribriform plate/orbital wall. MRI: Detects orbital or intracranial extension. Biopsy: Confirms the tumour type; it may be low-grade with pseudorosette formation or high-grade with nuclear pleomorphism but no rosette formation. Treatment: Craniofacial resection, with or without preoperative radiation or chemotherapy, followed by adjuvant radiation for advanced cases. Staging Systems: Kadish Staging System (with Morita’s Modification): Stage A Tumour limited to the nasal cavity. Stage B Tumour involving the nasal cavity and sinuses. Stage C Tumour extending beyond the nasal and paranasal sinuses. Stage D Tumor with metastasis to cervical nodes or distant sites. Other Staging Systems: Morita’s Staging System Dulguerov and Calcaterra Staging System Breslow Classification (Option B) is used for staging melanoma based on the thickness of the tumor. Ann Arbor Staging Classification (Option C) is used for staging lymphomas. Gleason Classification (Option D) is used for grading prostate cancer based on the pattern of tumor cells. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page - 239 Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition, Page - 80

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with a history of frontal headache, noticeable swelling on the forehead, and a recent episode of sinusitis. Physical examination reveals a soft, doughy swelling over the frontal bone, and a CT scan shows a subperiosteal abscess with associated bone erosion. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pott's Puffy Tumour Explanation: The Patient's acute presentation, doughy swelling , and subperiosteal abscess with bone erosion are classic features of Pott's puffy tumor. Pott's Puffy Tumour: It refers to a subperiosteal abscess or cellulitis of the frontal bone, commonly associated with frontal osteomyelitis. Typically presents with headache, swelling, and sometimes a discharging frontal fistula. Fig: Pott's Puffy Tumour Pus Formation: This can occur externally under the periosteum (resulting in a soft, doughy swelling ) or internally as an extradural abscess. Complications: Intracranial Spread : The infection can spread posteriorly, potentially leading to intracranial complications, reported in 30% to 60% of cases. This spread can occur via: Erosion of the posterior table of the frontal bone Septic thrombophlebitis through diploic veins Management: Antibiotics and Drainage: High-dose antibiotics (culture-directed, covering both aerobic and anaerobic organisms) for 6–8 weeks. Drainage : Performed endoscopically/trephination of the sinus floor. Surgical Approaches: Limited Subperiosteal Abscess: Lynch Howarth brow incision may be used, though it doesn’t provide full access. Spectacle Incision: Provides good exposure to the frontal sinus but leaves a cosmetic scar. Bicoronal Scalp Incision: Complex procedure. Offers excellent access to the frontal sinus and allows for the removal of diseased bone. Riedel’s Procedure: For, Extensive anterior table osteomyelitis, which involves removing the anterior wall and floor of the frontal sinus, with reconstruction performed later to address cosmetic deformity. Frontal Sinus

questions.question: Match the following conditions with their most commonly affected sinuses: Conditions Most Commonly Affected Sinus 1. Osteoma a. Maxillary sinus 2. Fibrous Dysplasia b. Ethmoid sinus 3. Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps c. Frontal sinus
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-a, 3-b Explanation: Osteoma: Most common in the frontal sinus. Fig: X-ray showing Osteoma in frontal sinus Fibrous Dysplasia: Most common in the maxillary sinus. Chronic Rhinosinusoitis with Polyps: Most common in the ethmoid sinuses. Condition Definition Most Common Site Clinical Features Management Osteoma Benign, slow-growing bony tumor affecting the paranasal sinuses. Frontal sinus (most common), ethmoid, maxillary Often asymptomatic; may cause sinus obstruction, mucocele formation, pressure symptoms (headache, orbital involvement). Observation for asymptomatic cases; surgical excision for deformity, obstruction, or symptomatic cases. Fibrous Dysplasia Benign fibro-osseous condition where bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, causing structural weakness and deformity. Maxillary sinus (most common), ethmoid, frontal Facial disfigurement, nasal obstruction, eye displacement, facial pain, and swelling. Chronic Rhinosinusitis with Nasal Polyps Chronic inflammatory condition with nasal polyps formation. Ethmoid sinuses (most common) Nasal obstruction, postnasal drip, anosmia/hyposmia, facial pressure, secondary infections, erosion into orbit or brain. Medical management (corticosteroids, antihistamines, nasal irrigations); surgery (FESS) for obstructive polyps.

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and a mass in the right nasal cavity. Nasal endoscopy reveals a mass arising from the lateral nasal wall with displacement of the middle turbinate. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of inverted papilloma. All of the following are true regarding inverted papilloma except?

options.B: It is associated with Human Papillomavirus type 6 and11.
options.C: The primary treatment involves endoscopic surgical excision.
options.D: It commonly arises from the non-olfactory mucosa.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) It is malignant at presentation . Explanation: Inverted papilloma is benign at presentation but carries a risk of malignant transformation into squamous cell carcinoma in 10-15% of cases. Inverted Papilloma Origin Arises from the non-olfactory mucosa (Schneiderian membrane) of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses Other Names Transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, Schneiderian papilloma Most Common Site Lateral wall of the nose , particularly in the middle meatus. Growth Pattern Inward growth of hyperplastic tissue toward the stroma. Association with HPV Linked to Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection (particularly types 6 and 11 ) Risk of Malignancy Associated with squamous cell carcinoma in 10-15% of cases. Symptoms Unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and possible recurrent sinus infections. Diagnosis Endoscopic examination and biopsy for histopathological confirmation. Treatment Primary treatment is complete endoscopic surgical excision to minimize the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a history of chronic sinusitis presents with worsening frontal headaches, orbital pain, diplopia, and ptosis. Examination reveals limited eye movements, decreased sensation over the forehead, and mild proptosis. Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome (SOFS) is suspected. Which cranial nerve is not involved in SOFS?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) CN II Explanation: Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome (SOFS) occurs when the structures passing through the superior orbital fissure are compromised, typically due to infection, trauma, or tumors. One of the most common sources of infection is the sphenoid sinus, which lies close to the fissure. Fig: Superior Orbital Fissure Anatomy Feature Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome (SOFS) Location Superior orbital fissure (between lesser and greater wings of sphenoid bone) Affected Structures Cranial Nerves (CN III, IV, VI,V 1 ) Common Causes Infections (sphenoid sinusitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis) Tumors (meningioma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, metastases) Trauma (sphenoid fractures) Symptoms Ophthalmoplegia (eye movement paralysis), ptosis (drooping eyelid), diplopia (double vision), frontal headache. Potential Complications Vision loss, impaired eye movement, facial numbness or pain Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 233,246 Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition page 3439,3444.

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with a recent history of sinusitis. The patient has sudden-onset high fever, severe headache, eyelid swelling, and restricted eye movements. Examination reveals bilateral proptosis and sequential cranial nerve palsies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Cavernous sinus thrombosis Explanation: Cavernous sinus thrombosis characterized by sudden onset of fever, headache, and bilateral involvement due to the midline location of the cavernous sinus. It commonly presents with sequential cranial nerve palsies (affecting CN III, IV, V, and VI), proptosis, and potentially severe visual disturbances. Fig: Cavernous sinus Differences Between Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis and Orbital Cellulitis: Feature Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis Orbital Cellulitis (Option A) Onset Sudden, high fever and headache. Gradual, starts with eyelid swelling. Involvement Frequently bilateral Typically unilateral Cranial Nerve Involvement Sequential palsy of CN III, IV, V1, VI It may involve cranial nerves Proptosis Bilateral proptosis common Usually unilateral proptosis Visual Loss More likely to cause severe visual loss It can cause visual impairment but is less severe Source of Infection Broad (sinusitis, pharyngitis, ear, orbit) Typically, it is from ethmoid sinusitis. Subperiosteal abscess (Option C) presents with localised abscess formation and may cause proptosis, but it is not associated with bilateral eye involvement or cranial nerve palsies. Preseptal cellulitis (Option D) is a more superficial infection affecting the tissues anterior to the orbital septum, causing eyelid swelling but without affecting eye movements or cranial nerves. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 233,234.

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient has been experiencing nasal congestion, facial pain, and nasal discharge for one week. Examination reveals maxillary sinus tenderness and nasal obstruction. The patient reports similar episodes resolving within 10-14 days. What is the most common cause of this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Viral infection Explanation: The symptoms suggest acute sinusitis , most commonly caused by a viral infection from upper respiratory viruses like rhinovirus, influenza, or parainfluenza. Allergic fungal sinusitis (Option B) is typically associated with chronic sinusitis, not acute episodes, and is more common in patients with atopy or asthma. Chronic Sinusitis is defined as inflammation of the sinuses and nasal passages lasting more than 12 weeks despite medical treatment. It is characterised by symptoms such as nasal obstruction, facial pain or pressure, nasal discharge, and a reduction in the sense of smell. Causes of Chronic Sinusitis Category Contributing Factors Patient Factors Anatomic structural deformities : Obstruction of sinus ostia (e.g., deviated septum, concha bullosa, anatomical variations) (Option A) Lifestyle factors : Smoking, snuff dipping, prolonged use of intranasal medications Immune Deficiency Primary : IgG deficiency, primary ciliary dyskinesia, cystic fibrosis Acquired : HIV, prolonged steroid use, chemotherapy, immunosuppressants in organ transplant patients, leukaemia Aspirin Sensitivity Sensitivity to aspirin causing chronic airway inflammation. (Option D) Environmental Factors Aeroallergens : Allergic rhinitis, asthma, exposure to allergens (dust, pollen, moulds) Toxins and Chemicals : Exposure to pollution, occupational chemicals, and toxic gases. Pathogens Bacteria (aerobic and anaerobic), fungi, mycobacteria Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 226.

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with sinusitis symptoms, including severe headache, nasal congestion, and fever. Examination reveals proptosis and restricted eye movements. A CT scan shows inflammation of the ethmoid sinuses. Which of the following is not a potential complication of sinusitis with orbital involvement?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sinus mucocele Explanation: A sinus mucocele is a chronic cyst filled with mucus, usually due to blocked sinus drainage. It typically results from chronic sinusitis rather than an acute infection and does not involve acute orbital complications like proptosis or restricted eye movement. Complications of Sinusitis: Local Complications: Mucocele It commonly involves Frontal sinus Presentation: Superomedial orbit (90% of cases) causing eye displacement forward, downward, and laterally; sometimes as cystic swelling in the forehead (10%). Symptoms: Mild headache, diplopia, and proptosis. Imaging: Clouded sinus with loss of scalloped outline. Treatment: Frontoethmoidectomy and drainage. Pyocele (Mucopyocele) Similar to mucocele but contains pus due to infection. Treatment involves endoscopic or external surgical drainage. Osteomyelitis Maxilla: More common in infants and children due to spongy bone. Symptoms: Erythema, Swelling, and Purulent discharge. Frontal Bone: Often occurs in adults & results from acute infection of frontal sinus. Symptoms: Pott’s puffy tumour or an extradural, subperiosteal abscess managed with frontal sinus trephination with Lynch Howarth incision. Orbital Complications: Inflammatory Oedema of Lids Subperiosteal Abscess (Option B) Orbital Cellulitis (Option A) Orbital Abscess (Option C) Superior Orbital Fissure Syndrome : Affects cranial nerves III, IV, VI and ophthalmic division of cranial nerve V, leading to pain and paralysis. Orbital Apex Syndrome: Includes symptoms of superior orbital fissure syndrome with additional involvement of the optic nerve and maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. Intracranial Complications: Meningitis and Encephalitis Extradural Abscess Subdural Abscess Brain Abscess Cavernous Sinus Thrombosis: Often results from infections of the ethmoid and sphenoid sinuses Descending Infections: Otitis Media: Acute or chronic, secondary to sinus discharge. Pharyngitis and Tonsillitis: Chronic sinusitis may lead to hypertrophy of pharyngeal lymphoid tissue or recurrent tonsillitis. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Pages 231-34

questions.question: A 55-year-old diabetic patient presents with facial swelling and necrotic nasal tissue, as shown in the image & visual changes. A diagnosis of acute invasive fungal rhinosinusitis (AIFR) is suspected. Which imaging modality is most appropriate for evaluating the extent of orbital/Intracranial involvement?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) CE-MRI Explanation: MRI with contrast is superior for assessing soft tissue involvement, including the extent of orbital and intracranial disease spread. It provides detailed images of the orbit, brain, and soft tissues, making it ideal for complex cases of AIFR with potential intracranial involvement. Mucormycosis Description A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction. Characteristic Findings Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI. Risk Factors Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment) Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants,

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient is evaluated for suspected allergic fungal rhinosinusitis (AFRS) using the Bent and Kuhn diagnostic criteria. Which of the following is not part of the Bent and Kuhn Major criteria for diagnosing AFRS?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Positive fungal cultures Explanation: The presence of fungal growth in cultures is a minor criterion, not a major one. Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS): Non-invasive fungal disease commonly affects younger individuals, especially those in warm, humid climates and lower socio-economic conditions. Common causative organism: Aspergillus . Atopic individuals are more prone to AFRS. Symptoms: Unilateral or bilateral nasal congestion, post-nasal drip, and thick, dark nasal discharge. CT Scan: Shows pansinusitis, hyper attenuated intrasinus contents (allergic mucin), and potential erosion of sinus walls due to inflammation. Bent and Kuhn Diagnostic Criteria for AFRS: Major Criteria (must meet all) Minor Criteria (supportive) Type I hypersensitivity (history, skin test, or in vitro testing) Nasal polyposis (Option A) Characteristic CT findings Eosinophilic mucin without fungal invasion (Option B) Positive fungal stain (Option D) Asthma Unilateral disease Radiological bone erosion Fungal cultures (Option C) Serum eosinophilia Charcot-Leyden crystals Reference: Scott Brown ENT, 8th Edition, Page - 212

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms such as a persistent headache and pain in the forehead region, indicating possible frontal sinusitis. Which imaging view is most suitable for evaluating the frontal sinuses in this situation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Caldwell's view Explanation: Caldwell’s view, also known as the occipitofrontal view, is specifically designed to visualise the frontal sinuses best. Imaging Views of the Paranasal Sinuses: X-Ray View Position Structures Seen Waters’ View (Occipitomental View or Nose-Chin Position): (Option B) The patient's nose and chin touch the film while the X-ray beam is projected. For enhanced visualisation, an open-mouth view is preferred to display the sphenoid sinus (Pierre’s View) Maxillary Sinuses: Best visualised. Frontal Sinuses Sphenoid Sinus: Visible if the mouth is open (Pierre’s View) Zygoma & Zygomatic Arch Nasal Bone Frontal Process of Maxilla Superior Orbital Fissure Infratemporal Fossa Caldwell View (Occipitofrontal View or Nose-Forehead Position): The patient’s nose and forehead touch the film & X-ray beam projected 15-20° caudally. Frontal Sinuses: Best visualised. Ethmoid Sinuses Maxillary Sinuses Frontal Process of Zygoma Zygomatic Process of Frontal Bone Superior Margin of Orbit and Lamina Papyracea Superior Orbital Fissure Lateral View: (Option C) The lateral side of the skull is against the film with the X-ray beam projected perpendicular from the other side. Sphenoid Sinus: Anterior and posterior extent. Frontal Sinus (highest sinus on lateral view) Maxillary Sinus Sella Turcica Zygoma and Zygomatic Arch Mandible: Including coronoid and condyloid processes Submentovertical (Basal) View: (Option D) The X-ray beam is projected from below the chin towards the top of the head. Sphenoid Sinus Posterior Ethmoid Sinuses Maxillary Sinuses Right and Left Oblique Views: To view the posterior ethmoid sinuses and the optic foramen of the corresponding side. Structures Seen: Posterior ethmoid sinuses and optic foramen.

questions.question: A patient who underwent Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS) presents with persistent nasal discharge and facial pain. During the follow-up, the surgeon considers various potential complications. Which of the following is not a common complication of FESS?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Fractured nasal bones Explanation: Fractured nasal bones are not a common complication of Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS). Nasal bone fractures are more related to trauma or external injury than complications directly resulting from FESS. Functional Endoscopic Surgery of the Sinuses (FESS): Designed to restore proper drainage and ventilation of the sinuses using a rigid Endoscope, which provides superior illumination and magnification, improving precision. Preoperative Considerations: Preoperative Imaging: Evaluating the middle meatal area and identifying Onodi cells and critical structures like the optic nerve and internal carotid artery. Rule-out Conditions: Cribiform plate (Low-lying): Check the depth of the fossa (8-10 mm) Lamina papyracea: Assess for dehiscence or damage risks. Optic nerve: Evaluate proximity and risk of injury. Sphenoid sinus: Check for dehiscence of the lateral wall. Ethmoidal artery (Anterior): Risk of injury should be assessed. Surgical Techniques: Uncinectomy: This is an essential initial step in FESS to access the sinuses, and it should be performed carefully to avoid damage to the orbital and cranial structures. Removal of the Ethmoidal Bulla Posterior Ethmoidectomy Sphenoidotomy Frontal Sinus Surgery Complications of FESS: Hemorrhage It is often associated with injury to the anterior ethmoidal artery or excessive middle turbinate resection. Control bleeding with vasoconstrictors or bipolar diathermy; manage severe cases with topical hemostats or direct repair. Orbital Injury (Option A) First incision or during middle meatal antrostomy. Orbital Hematoma Associated with injury to the anterior ethmoidal artery Risk if orbital fat is exposed; requires immediate management. Optic Nerve Injury (Option B) Possible from intra-orbital hematoma or direct damage. CSF Leak (Option C) Risk around the vertical lamella of the cribriform plate. Immediate repair is usually effective, using fat plugs, artificial materials, or fibrin glue. Carotid Artery Injury It is rare but catastrophic, especially during sphenoid surgery. Immediate hemostatic resuscitation and sphenoid packing are essential; consider endovascular stenting as an alternative to direct repair. Post Surgery Complication Synechiae Formation: Prevented by nasal packing with Mitomycin C in the middle meatal area.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with symptoms of sinusitis, including nasal obstruction, facial pain, and thick nasal discharge, persisting for the past 6 months. The patient has failed to respond to a course of antibiotics and nasal corticosteroids. What is the step in management to evaluate the extent of sinus involvement ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Non-Contrast CT Explanation: Non-Contrast CT of the Sinus is typically used as the initial imaging modality for diagnosing and evaluating chronic sinusitis . It helps in visualising the extent of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and anatomical abnormalities such as polyps and structural obstructions. Contrast-enhanced CT (Option B) Used when there is a need to assess for more complex cases or complications, such as the spread of infection to adjacent structures or suspected malignancy. It provides an enhanced visualisation of vascular structures. X-ray (Option C) provides limited detail with poor sensitivity and specificity, making it less effective in evaluating chronic sinusitis and generally not preferred compared to CT. HRCT (Option D) offers detailed imaging of the lungs and temporal bones, making it ideal for evaluating interstitial lung diseases like idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis and sarcoidosis, as well as detecting conditions such as cholesteatoma and otosclerosis in the temporal bone.

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient with acute sinusitis has had worsening symptoms for ten days. The patient has moderate fever, facial pain, and purulent nasal discharge. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Oral Amoxicillin with clavulanic acid Explanation: Antibiotics are a critical component of treatment for acute bacterial sinusitis, particularly when symptoms have persisted or worsened for more than 7-10 days. Amoxicillin with clavulanic acid is a first-line choice due to its broad-spectrum coverage and effectiveness against common pathogens causing bacterial sinusitis, including Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae. Management of Acute Sinusitis Management Aspect Description Indications Antibiotics First-line: Oral Amoxicillin with clavulanic acid Alternatives: Doxycycline, Levofloxacin Duration: Typically 7-14 days Persistent symptoms lasting >7-10 days. Intranasal Corticosteroids Fluticasone, Mometasone (Reduces mucosal inflammation and improves sinus drainage) Adjunctive therapy Significant mucosal swelling Concurrent allergic rhinitis Saline Irrigations Helps in thinning mucus and flushing bacteria. Symptomatic relief and improves mucus clearance. Topical Nasal Decongestants Oxymetazoline, Xylometazoline Provides symptomatic relief. Short-term use only and avoid prolonged use to prevent rebound congestion. Surgical Intervention Endoscopic sinus surgery For chronic or complicated sinusitis Severe cases unresponsive to medical therapy Complications such as orbital cellulitis Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 223

questions.question: A 32-year-old patient presents with complaints of retro-orbital pain and occasional visual disturbances. CT imaging of the sinuses reveals a posterior ethmoid air cell extending superiorly and laterally to the sphenoid sinus, impinging on the optic nerve. What is the most likely anatomical variant responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Onodi cell Explanation: Onodi Cell is a posterior ethmoid air cell that extends superiorly and laterally to the sphenoid sinus, close to the optic nerve. Compression of the optic nerve can lead to retro-orbital pain and visual disturbances. Sinus Cell Location Clinical Significance Agger Nasi Cell Most anterior ethmoid cell, located above the lacrimal sac and below the frontal sinus. Often involved in frontal sinus drainage issues. Onodi Cell Posterior ethmoid cell extending superiorly and laterally towards the sphenoid sinus, near the optic nerve . It may cause retro-orbital pain and visual disturbances due to proximity to the optic nerve. Haller Cells Infraorbital ethmoid cells extending into the floor of the orbit. It can obstruct the maxillary sinus ostium, leading to maxillary sinusitis and occasionally orbital symptoms. Frontal Recess Cell Located in the frontal recess area. It can affect frontal sinus drainage.

questions.question: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of a dull headache, post-nasal drip, and retro-orbital pain. On nasal endoscopy, pus is noted draining from the superior meatus. What type of sinusitis is most likely indicated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Posterior ethmoid sinusitis Explanation: The superior meatus is the drainage site for the posterior ethmoid sinus, so pus in this area indicates sinus involvement. Retro-orbital pain, a dull headache, and post-nasal drip support a diagnosis of posterior ethmoid sinusitis. Sinus Type Drainage Common Symptoms Posterior ethmoid sinusitis Superior meatus Retro-orbital pain, headache Sphenoid sinusitis Sphenoethmoidal recess Occipital headache, generalised dull headache Anterior ethmoid sinusitis Middle meatus Pain between eyes, nasal congestion Maxillary sinusitis Cheek pain, toothache Frontal sinusitis Frontal headache, forehead tenderness Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 222-225

questions.question: A 35-year-old patient presents with facial pain, nasal congestion, and purulent nasal discharge for the past 12 days. Examination reveals tenderness over the maxillary sinuses and fever of 38°C. Which of the following is considered a major criterion for diagnosing acute sinusitis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Facial pain Explanation: Facial pain is a hallmark symptom and one of the major criteria for diagnosis of Acute sinusitis. Major and Minor Criteria for Acute Sinusitis Diagnosis: Major Criteria Minor Criteria Facial pain/pressure Nasal obstruction/congestion Purulent nasal discharge Hyposmia/Anosmia Fever Headache Dental pain Ear fullness Cough Halitosis (bad breath) 2 Major or 1 Major and 2 Minor criteria are required to diagnose acute sinusitis. Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose, Throat - PL Dhingra, 8th edition, Page 222 Cumming’s review of otolaryngology, Page 65
